subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Is this group defunct?
msgSnippet: I was considering that automated translation would work if you mapped the IPA pronunciation characters to Read alphabet characters. You d have to have the
messageBody:
I was considering that automated translation would work if you mapped the IPA pronunciation characters to Read alphabet characters. 
You'd have to have the problem of which pronunciation to use, but most people would get it whichever one you used. The important question is how you write GIF in Read of course. 😀
Also, don't think I'm closely related to any Terry Drinkwater, but probably distantly.
-Tev

On Jul 16, 2017 5:16 PM, "mailinglists@... [Read_Alphabet]" <Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com> wrote:
 

It looks neat if you're going for a Hebrew vibe, but I'm 99% sure it has even fewer vowel sounds than Quikscript.


On Sun, Jul 16, 2017, at 04:02 AM, John Kane jrkrideau@... [Read_Alphabet] wrote:
 


HI John,
Have you had a look at http://unspell.blogspot.ca/p/ home.html. The author claims it accomodates varioius dialects.



On Saturday, July 15, 2017, 10:54:24 PM EDT, John Cowan cowan@... [Read_Alphabet] <Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com > wrote:


 



On Sat, Jul 15, 2017 at 1:12 PM, Vincent Reilly vin.reilly@... [Read_Alphabet] <Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com > wrote:

1. Would it be desirable to create an English Academy, modeled on the Academie Française? Would it even be possible?

Let's not.  The AF is a horrible model.  It takes forever to do anything, its dictionary is neither very good nor very authoritative in actual use (though it is theoretically official in France), it has a history of opposing all recognition of the regional languages of France.  Of the 35 present members (five seats are vacant), only six were born outside France and only one (Haitian Canadian Dany Laferrière) is living outside France; this despite the fact that less than a third of French-speakers live in France. 

2. If the Read Alphabet were widely adopted, might we no longer see the value of standardization, in favor of spelling how you speak? Is this a bad thing or a good thing?

Historically, standardization has been something publishers have insisted on.  If every author spells just as they like, the result is orthographic chaos, and proofreading becomes impossible.  Even Cherokee, which was not written until the 19C, has a fairly well-established standard spelling that doesn't agree exactly with any one of the various dialects of Cherokee, themselves products of the 19C as well.

At present, orthographies are stabilized by a feedback loop between publishers and lexicographers.  Publishers adopt a particular dictionary as their authority for spelling, but the spellings that appear in dictionaries are those used by publishers.  The process rapidly converges on a standard orthography without any single source of authority.

3. One way to standardize phonetic spelling to standardize a proper manner of speaking. (I think this refers back to question 1). Should one accent be considered "standard"?And which one? And why?

That's hopeless.  The matter would instantly become a political football (round or oval) between the U.S. and the UK, with the rest of the world acting as something between astonished bystanders and swing voters.

What can, and I believe should, be done is to establish a writing system that makes the distinctions required by any of the living accents of Standard English.  In this way, English-speakers would easily be able to pronounce any written word according to their own accent, but would have to learn in some cases how a word should be written so as to be read correctly by all English-speakers.  The Read alphabet already provides this in the matter of post-vocalic "r", but would need a few more letters to cover all the vowel sounds of English.

For example Read has only one letter for the sounds of "term", "dirt", and "nurse", but would require three for Scottish English, which pronounces them all differently, and for Irish English, which pronounces two of them the same but the other differently.  (Note that traditional orthography already caters to this requirement.)  This would be a small burden for other writers of English, but would eliminate the notion that some accents are preferred to others, as there is no internationally preferred accent.

phabet@yahoogroups.com> wrote:
>
> 1. Would it be desirable to create an En=
glish Academy, modeled on the
> Academie Fran=C3=A7aise? Would it even be p=
ossible?
>
> Let's not.  The AF is a horrible model.  It takes forever to d=
o anything,
> its dictionary is neither very good nor very authoritative in=
 actual use
> (though it is theoretically official in France), it has a his=
tory of
> opposing all recognition of the regional languages of France.  Of=
 the 35
> present members (five seats are vacant), only six were born outsi=
de France
> and only one (Haitian Canadian Dany Laferri=C3=A8re) is living =
outside France;
> this despite the fact that less than a third of French-sp=
eakers live in
> France.
>
> 2. If the Read Alphabet were widely adopted, m=
ight we no longer see the
> value of standardization, in favor of spelling =
how you speak? Is this a bad
> thing or a good thing?
>
> Historically, sta=
ndardization has been something publishers have insisted
> on.  If every au=
thor spells just as they like, the result is orthographic
> chaos, and proo=
freading becomes impossible.  Even Cherokee, which was not
> written until =
the 19C, has a fairly well-established standard spelling that
> doesn't agr=
ee exactly with any one of the various dialects of Cherokee,
> themselves p=
roducts of the 19C as well.
>
> At present, orthographies are stabilized by=
 a feedback loop between
> publishers and lexicographers.  Publishers adopt=
 a particular dictionary as
> their authority for spelling, but the spellin=
gs that appear in dictionaries
> are those used by publishers.  The process=
 rapidly converges on a standard
> orthography without any single source of=
 authority.
>
> 3. One way to standardize phonetic spelling to standardize =
a proper manner
> of speaking. (I think this refers back to question 1). Sh=
ould one accent be
> considered "standard"?And which one? And why?
>
> That=
's hopeless.  The matter would instantly become a political football
> (rou=
nd or oval) between the U.S. and the UK, with the rest of the world
> actin=
g as something between astonished bystanders and swing voters.
>
> What can=
, and I believe should, be done is to establish a writing system
> that mak=
es the distinctions required by any of the living accents of
> Standard Eng=
lish.  In this way, English-speakers would easily be able to
> pronounce an=
y written word according to their own accent, but would have to
> learn in =
some cases how a word should be written so as to be read correctly
> by all=
 English-speakers.  The Read alphabet already provides this in the
> matter=
 of post-vocalic "r", but would need a few more letters to cover all
> the =
vowel sounds of English.
>
> For example Read has only one letter for the s=
ounds of "term", "dirt", and
> "nurse", but would require three for Scottis=
h English, which pronounces
> them all differently, and for Irish English, =
which pronounces two of them
> the same but the other differently.  (Note t=
hat traditional orthography
> already caters to this requirement.)  This wo=
uld be a small burden for
> other writers of English, but would eliminate t=
he notion that some accents
> are preferred to others, as there is no inter=
nationally preferred accent.
>
>
>
>
>
>

--94eb2c0d7b72d5bb7605547d9519

<div dir=3D"auto">I was considering that automated translation would work i=
f you mapped the IPA pronunciation characters to Read alphabet characters.=
=C2=A0<div dir=3D"auto">You'd have to have the problem of which pronunc=
iation to use, but most people would get it whichever one you used. The imp=
ortant question is how you write GIF in Read of course. =F0=9F=98=80</div><=
div dir=3D"auto">Also, don't think I'm closely related to any Terry=
 Drinkwater, but probably distantly.</div><div dir=3D"auto">-Tev</div></div=

<div><div>On Sat, Jul 15, 2017 =
at 1:12 PM, Vincent Reilly <a shape=3D"rect" href=3D"mailto:vin.reilly@veri=
zon.net" target=3D"_blank">vin.reilly@...</a> [Read_Alphabet] <span=

.com" target=3D"_blank">Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com</a><wbr>></span> w=
rote:<br></div>
<blockquote style=3D"margin:0px 0px 0px 0.8ex;border-left-w=
idth:1px;border-left-style:solid;border-left-color:rgb(204,204,204)"><p sty=
le=3D"margin:0px 0px 1em">1. Would it be desirable to create an English Aca=
demy, modeled on
      the Academie Fran=C3=A7aise? Would it even be possib=
le?<br></p></blockquote><div>Let's not.=C2=A0 The AF is a horrible mode=
l.=C2=A0 It takes forever to do anything, its dictionary is neither very go=
od nor very authoritative in actual use (though it is theoretically officia=
l in France), it has a history of opposing all recognition of the regional =
languages of France.=C2=A0 Of the 35 present members (five seats are vacant=
), only six were born outside France and only one (Haitian Canadian Dany La=
ferri=C3=A8re) is living outside France; this despite the fact that less th=
an a third of French-speakers live in France.=C2=A0<br></div>
<blockquote s=
tyle=3D"margin:0px 0px 0px 0.8ex;border-left-width:1px;border-left-style:so=
lid;border-left-color:rgb(204,204,204)"><p style=3D"margin:0px 0px 1em">2. =
If the Read Alphabet were widely adopted, might we no longer
      see the =
value of standardization, in favor of spelling how you
      speak? Is this=
 a bad thing or a good thing?<br></p></blockquote><div>Historically, standa=
rdization has been something publishers have insisted on.=C2=A0 If every au=
thor spells just as they like, the result is orthographic chaos, and proofr=
eading becomes impossible.=C2=A0 Even Cherokee, which was not written until=
 the 19C, has a fairly well-established standard spelling that doesn't =
agree exactly with any one of the various dialects of Cherokee, themselves =
products of the 19C as well.<br></div>
<div><br></div>
<div>At present, ort=
hographies are stabilized by a feedback loop between publishers and lexicog=
raphers.=C2=A0 Publishers adopt a particular dictionary as their authority =
for spelling, but the spellings that appear in dictionaries are those used =
by publishers.=C2=A0 The process rapidly converges on a standard orthograph=
y without any single source of authority.<br></div>
<blockquote style=3D"ma=
rgin:0px 0px 0px 0.8ex;border-left-width:1px;border-left-style:solid;border=
-left-color:rgb(204,204,204)"><p style=3D"margin:0px 0px 1em">3. One way to=
 standardize phonetic spelling to standardize a
      proper manner of spea=
king. (I think this refers back to question
      1). Should one accent be =
considered "standard"?And which one? And
      why?<br></p></bloc=
kquote></div>
<div>That's hopeless.=C2=A0 The matter would instantly be=
come a political football (round or oval) between the U.S. and the UK, with=
 the rest of the world acting as something between astonished bystanders an=
d swing voters.<br></div>
</div>
<div><br></div>
<div>What can, and I belie=
ve should, be done is to establish a writing system that makes the distinct=
ions required by any of the living accents of Standard English.=C2=A0 In th=
is way, English-speakers would easily be able to pronounce any written word=
 according to their own accent, but would have to learn in some cases how a=
 word should be written so as to be read correctly by all English-speakers.=
=C2=A0 The Read alphabet already provides this in the matter of post-vocali=
c "r", but would need a few more letters to cover all the vowel s=
ounds of English.<br></div>
<div><br></div>
<div><div>For example Read has =
only one letter for the sounds of "term", "dirt", and &=
quot;nurse", but would require three for Scottish English, which prono=
unces them all differently, and for Irish English, which pronounces two of =
them the same but the other differently. =C2=A0(Note that traditional ortho=
graphy already caters to this requirement.) =C2=A0This would be a small bur=
den for other writers of English, but would eliminate the notion that some =
accents are preferred to others, as there is no internationally preferred a=
ccent.<br></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
